text: for the last 13 years NASA's Cassini
spacecraft has spied on Saturn and its
many moons turns out this region of
space could hold the greatest secrets of
our solar system here are five of the
most fascinating discoveries Cassini has
given us so far
number one the possibility of alien life
before Cassini Saturn's neighborhood was
relatively average today it's revered as
one of the most likely places to
discover alien life
Cassini first discovered powerful
geysers on Saturn's moon Enceladus the
geysers later revealed a global
subsurface ocean by diving through these
plumes Cassini found key chemicals that
suggest hydrothermal vents line at sea
floor on earth environments like these
are teeming with life so why not on
Enceladus - number two space lakes
before Cassini little was known about
Saturn's moon Titan now we know it's
more earth-like than scientists could
have ever imagined Cassini's Huygens
probe first landed on Titan in 2005 what
it saw was the first ever lakes beyond
Earth Titan is the only place besides
Earth with lakes rainstorms and tides
but unlike Earth these are made of
liquid methane not water to date Titan
is the farthest moon where any space
probe has landed number three space
storms in 2010 the biggest storm in our
solar system's history came to life
Cassini's instruments detected signs of
thunder and lightning on Saturn it
measured temperatures in the storm
spiking to 150 degrees Fahrenheit the
updraft would have been powerful enough
to blow away Earth's entire atmosphere
within months Cassini saw the storm rap
190,000 miles around Saturn that's far
enough to encircle Earth seven and a
half times this went on for nearly a
year before the storm finally died down
number four secrets in Saturn's rings in
2013 Cassini spotted what could be the
formation of a new moon the discovery
suggests Saturn once had an even greater
ring system these ancient rings could
have been where Titan and Enceladus
formed Plus Cassini proved Saturn's
rings aren't uniformly flat these
shadows revealed towering structures one
and a half miles tall it's possible that
unseen moons hidden in Saturn's rings
created them number five mysterious
clouds Saturn's North Pole has something
unique to the entire solar system
it's called Saturn's hexagon the
six-sided shape of these clouds are a
topic of debate Cassini hasn't solved
the mystery but it has revealed that the
central vortex is deeper than expected
it sinks 60 miles below Saturn's cloud
tops Cassini conjured another puzzle in
2016 when it saw the hexagon
mysteriously changed colors from blue to
gold in 2004 Cassini became the first
spacecraft to ever orbit Saturn
[Music]
you
